) Purpose: This IRM provides guidance and instructions for Section
Manager’s Self-Certiﬁcation and the Human Capital Office (HCO) Review process designed to support IRS’ compliance with the Reform and structuring Act of
(RRA ‘
): a. Section
(a) prohibits the IRS from using any Records of Tax En- forcement Results (ROTERs) to evaluate employees or to impose or suggest production quotas or goals. b. Section
(b) requires that employees be evaluated using the fair equitable treatment of taxpayers as a performance standard. c. Section
(c) requires each appropriate supervisor to self-certify quarterly whether ROTERs were used in a prohibited manner. (
) Audience: The IRS business units subject to RRA ‘

which includes these organizations: a. The Independent Office of Appeals (Appeals) b. Criminal Investigation (CI) c. Large Business and International (LB&I) d. Small Business and Self-Employed SB/SE) e. Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) f. Tax Exempt and Government Entities (TE/GE) g. Wage and Investment (W&I) . (
) Policy Owner: The HCO administers the Section
program and IRS compliance with RRA
through: a. Section

Manager’s Quarterly Self-Certiﬁcation Reporting. b. Annual HCO Independent Reviews. c. Coordination with the Treasury Inspector General for Tax (TIGTA) for the annual “Statutory Audit of Compliance with Legal lines Restricting Use of Records of Tax Enforcement Results.” (
) Primary Stakeholders: This policy and procedures apply to the seven IRS business units that are subject to RRA ‘
compliance. (
) Program Goals: The Section

program is designed to identify and a. ROTER violations. b. Instances of non-compliance with the retention standard for the fair equitable treatment of taxpayers. c. Certiﬁcation process violations. (
) The Section
program is based on RRA ‘
, which requires the IRS to ensure that managers do not evaluate enforcement employees using or base employee successes on meeting ROTER goals and quotas. (
) Section

requires certain managers to complete quarterly self- certiﬁcations. It also requires the IRS to establish a retention standard for all employees that supports the “fair and equitable treatment of taxpayers.” (

) Employee Performance File (EPF)- A ﬁle maintained by the employee’s immediate supervisor consisting only of performance-related documents covering the past four years. (

) HR Connect - The IRS human resources system of record, owned and operated by the Department of the Treasury. Human resources managers and employees use HR Connect to perform a wide array of tions at various stages of an employee’s life cycle. Supervisors use HR Connect to manage human capital and better use organizational data for strategic decision making. (
) HR Connect Indicator- The HR Connect indicator identiﬁes Section
managers and employees within the HR Connect system. (

) Integrated Talent Management (ITM) - The IRS system of record for which gives employees and managers a better opportunity to develop, and promote career development which: a. Maintains employee learning and teaching histories. b. Launches online courses. c. Tracks completion of assigned curriculum and requirements. d. Offers development and delivery of course evaluations. e. Provides data reporting. (

) Manager - Is a position that: a. Directs the work of an organization through subordinate supervisors. b. Is accountable for the success of speciﬁc line or staff functions. c. Monitors and evaluates the progress of the organization toward goals. d. Makes adjustments in objectives, work plans, schedules, and commitments. e. Serves as head or assistant head of a major organization within a bureau. f. Directs a specialized program of marked difficulty, responsibility, and national signiﬁcance. (

) Records of Tax Enforcement Results (ROTERs) - Are data, statistics, compilations of information or other numerical or quantitative recordations the tax enforcement results reached in one or more cases. Examples of ROTERs include, but are not limited to: a. Number of liens ﬁled. b. Number of levies served. c. Number of seizures executed. d. Number of fraud referrals. e. Dollars per hour. f. Dollars per return. g. Total dollars assessed/collected. h. Percentage of agreed cases. i. Number of “full paid” cases. j. Number of prosecutions recommended. k. Percentage of Taxpayer Advocate cases where relief was granted. l. Amount of revenue protected. m. No change rate. (
) Retention Standard for the Fair and Equitable Treatment of Taxpayers (Retention Standard)- An IRS employee performance standard based on Section
(b), which requires that employees be evaluated on the fair equitable treatment provided to taxpayers and behaviors that meet or do meet the standard. (
) Section

Employee - An employee or manager of an employee (all of management) who exercises judgment in recommending or determining whether or how the IRS should pursue enforcement of tax laws, or an employee whose duties involve providing direction and/or guidance for ﬁeld programs involving Section
work activities, including IRM guidance. work activity performed, not the employee’s title, location, or business unit, identiﬁes whether an employee should be considered a Section
employee. Note: While many of the divisions in the Services and Enforcement organization are subject to Section
, there are offices that are not subject to
, such as the Whistleblower’s Office. (

indicator”. (

The ﬁrst lists the paragraph heading and the second column provides the corresponding details in the paragraph. The performance evaluation system for all other employees will:
Establish one or more retention standards for each employee related to the work of the employee and expressed in terms of individual performance
Require periodic determinations of whether each employee meets, or does not meet, the estab- lished retention standards
Require that action be taken in accordance with applicable laws and regulations, with respect to an employee whose performance does not meet the established retention standards
Establish goals or objectives for individual perfor- mance consistent with the IRS performance planning procedures
Use such goals and objectives to make perfor- mance distinctions among employees or groups of employees

Use performance assessments as a basis for granting employee awards, adjusting an employ- ee’s rate of basic pay, and other appropriate personnel actions, in accordance with applicable laws and regulations

No employee of the IRS may use records of tax enforcement results (as deﬁned in §

) to evaluate any other employee or to impose or suggest production quotas or goals for any employee. (i) For purposes of the limitation contained in this paragraph (e), the term employee has the meaning as deﬁned in
USC

(a). (ii) For purposes of the limitation contained in this paragraph (e), evaluate includes any process used to appraise or measure an em- ployee’s performance for purposes of providing the following: (A) Any required or requested per- formance rating. (B) A recommendation for an award covered by Chapter
of title
USC
; or Section

(a) of the Act. (C) An as- sessment of an employee’s qualiﬁcations for promotion, reassignment or other change in duties. (D) An assessment of an employee’s eligi- bility for incentives, allowances or bonuses. (E) Ranking of employees for release/recall and re- ductions in force.

Employees who are responsible for exercising judgment with respect to tax enforcement results in cases concerning one or more taxpayers may be evaluated on work done on such cases only in the context of their critical elements and standards.

Performance measures based in whole or in part on quantity measures will not be used to evaluate the performance of any non-supervisory who is responsible for exercising judgment with respect to tax enforcement results (as deﬁned in §
